text: mark Arden has a special relationship
with his horse like thousands of other
Mongolians he makes the trip out to the
countryside during this summer to
reconnect with his nomadic roots at the
annual nodame festival riding horses is
in his blood first time I rode a horse I
was very young I couldn't resist so I
mounted the horse and started galloping
my father got angry and yelled at me
after my first race and then a Dom
festival my father gave me seven
thousand tugrik and a pickled pair as a
present but if nomadic lifestyle
represents a harmonious balance between
Mongolians and nature it is being
overshadowed by an issue that is the
future for all Mongolians mining the
Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party
headquarters was burned down in recent
elections
claims over election fraud were just one
of several issues troubling the
fledgling democracy Mongolia is expected
to develop one of the world's largest
copper and gold resources called oh you
tole go with a potential yield of over 1
billion pounds of copper per year the
wealth generated from the mine is
expected to increase the GDP of mongolia
by thirty-four percent but Mongolians
are anxious about corruption and many
smaller political parties here have
played on local fears that well from the
mines will be unfairly distributed
between foreign companies investing in
them and corrupt government officials
fears are particularly acute amongst the
third of Mongolia's population that
